Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Approximate Computing Systems for Future Teraflops Workloads

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The performance of computers has improved tremendously in the past four decades, which has enabled innumerable applications that have major roles in our daily lives. However, without dramatic innovations in improving power efficiency of computing, the continued semiconductor device scaling alone will fail to provide sufficient performance for the future computing capabilities. For the emerging challenge, the proposed research investigates revolutionary computing paradigms to process, comprehend, and use abundant data in an extremely efficient way. The novelty of the approach lies in developing power- and performance-efficient computing systems with software support by exploiting the characteristics of future workloads that often use complex probabilistic mathematical models of physical phenomena. In such applications, approximate computing can often result in satisfactory outcomes. Meanwhile, it can dramatically decrease power consumption or increase performance by replacing complete logic functions with simplified circuits that mimic the functions for rough calculations. To extend the approximate computing concept to more general-purpose computing systems, the following holistic approaches are proposed: 1) intelligent microarchitectures to identify correctness-non-critical regions of code with compiler support; 2) approximate computing engines to execute such regions of code power and performance efficiently; 3) high-level morphic primitives to process a large fraction of workloads with orders-of-magnitude greater power and performance efficiency; and 4) flexible architectures to allow programmers and users to trade the quality of computing with the efficiency.

The proposed research will have a specific and significant impact on the computer architecture, circuit, and compiler communities since it requires analysis of interesting and representative workloads; realization of state-of-the-art circuit, architecture, and compiler infrastructure; and invention of powerful and useful evaluation methodologies. Since most of the development and research work will be conducted by graduate students, both industry and academia will benefit from well-educated and trained employees as well as direct technology transfer when students graduate and begin employment elsewhere. Finally, the success of this research will tremendously benefit our ability to advance human?s collective knowledge in science, technology, business, medicine, and virtually every other field of human endeavor by allowing remarkable improvement in computing performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has allowed the PI to explore a new computing paradigm that can dramatically improve energy efficiency of future computing systems for emerging application domains, also known as recognition, mining and synthesis (RMS). The PI observed that these applications can tolerate some imprecision in computation without notably affecting the final outcome and exploiting such application-level characteristics would substantially improve energy efficiency of computing systems (i.e., approximate computing). While performing the project, the PI developed many circuit, microarchitecture, and architecture-level techniques and demonstrated considerable improvement in energy efficiency. For example, the multiplier is the most frequently used arithmetic unit in many essential applications including signal processing and machine learning, while it consumes very high energy. A novel approximate multiplier proposed by the PI can improve energy efficiency by 11 times without notably affecting the perceptual quality and classification accuracy of signal processing and machine learning applications, respectively. Due to its simplicity and effectiveness, the PI expects that the developed multiplier can powerfully and cost-effectively enable a re-emerging computing paradigm, in-memory processing where the cost of logic functions was too high to be integrated in memory. As another example, the PI developed various processor architectures exploiting value similarity in computations. These processor architectures were able to dramatically improve energy efficiency as they considerably reduced the number of computations without the programmer’s intervention.

 

This timely research direction also coincided with a large body of approximate computing work during the project period, leading to one of major research trends in circuit, architecture, and software communities. Due to the PI’s pioneering effort on approximate computing, the PI has been invited to many activities such as a guest editor for a special issue on approximating computing for a prominent technical magazine and panelists for creating new research programs. Lastly, this grant allowed the PI to support and advise multiple graduate students including one under-represented student. After graduation these students joint prominent U.S. companies in the computer industry and have contributed to developing next-generation processors.
